<s> in the direct method af not further treated stained certain tissues of healthy sweet clover stems nonspecifically and wtv tumor sections were similarly stained by comparable af </s>
<s> the reason for the failure of these treatments to eliminate nonspecific staining in the conjugates in our system is not known </s>
<s> in our work the best procedure for removing substances causing nonspecific staining in order to obtain specific conjugates was to pass the conjugates through a deae-cellulose column and in some cases to absorb the first and second milliliter fractions with sweet clover tissue powder </s>
<s> the specific staining by both direct and indirect methods showed that wtv antigen was concentrated in the pseudophloem tissue and in a few thick-walled cells in the xylem region but was not detectable in any other tissues of the root and stem tumors </s>
<s> a study of the distribution of wtv antigen within the pseudophloem cells indicates that it is irregularly distributed in the cytoplasm </s>
<s> the concentration and apparent localization of the wtv antigen in pseudophloem tissue of the tumor may indicate that the virus preferentially multiplies in the phloem and may need to be directly placed in this tissue in order to infect plants </s>
<s> since emotional reactions in the higher vertebrates depend on individual experience and are aroused in man in addition by complex symbols one would expect that the hypothalamus could be excited from the cortex </s>
<s> in experiments with topical application of strychnine on the cerebral cortex the transmission of impulses from the cortex to the hypothalamus was demonstrated </s>
<s> moreover the responsiveness of the hypothalamus to nociceptive stimulation is greatly increased under these conditions </s>
<s> a previously extinguished conditioned reaction was restored in monkey a and was associated with typical signs of emotional excitement including sympathetic discharges </s>
<s> it seems to follow that by and large an antagonism exists between the paleo- and the neocortex as far as emotional reactivity is concerned and that the balance between the two systems determines the emotional responsiveness of the organism </s>
<s> but even in relatively primitive laboratory animals such as the rat sex activity closely identified with the hypothalamus and the visceral brain is enhanced by the neocortex </s>
<s> it should be added that in man neocortical-hypothalamic interrelations probably play a role in the fusion of emotional processes with those underlying perception memory imagination and creativity </s>
<s> previous experiences are obviously of great importance for the qualitative and quantitative emotional response </s>
<s> the visceral brain as well as the neocortex is known to contribute to memory but this topic is beyond the scope of this paper </s>
<s> hypothalamic balance and its significance </s>
<s> after this brief discussion of neo- paleocortical and cortico-hypothalamic relations let us return once more to the problem of hypothalamic balance and its physiological and pathological significance </s>
<s> facilitatory processes take place between neocortex and hypothalamus via ascending and descending pathways </s>
<s> thus cortico-fugal discharges induced by topical application of strychnine to a minute area in the neocortex summate with spikes present in the hypothalamus and cause increased convulsive discharges </s>
<s> on the other hand the temporary reduction in hypothalamic excitability through the injection of a barbiturate into the posterior hypothalamus causes a lessening in frequency and amplitude of cortical strychnine spikes until the hypothalamic excitability is restored </s>
<s> apparently a positive feedback exists between the posterior hypothalamus and the cerebral cortex </s>
<s> consequently if for any reason the hypothalamic excitability falls below the physiological level the lessened hypothalamic-cortical discharges lead to a diminished state of activity in the cortex with consequent reduction in the cortico-fugal discharges </s>
<s> obviously a vicious cycle develops </s>
<s> this tendency can be broken either by restoring hypothalamic excitability directly or via cortico-hypothalamic pathways </s>
<s> it is believed that drug therapy and electroshock involve the former and psychotherapy the latter mechanism </s>
<s> before we comment further on these pathological conditions we should remember that changes in the state of the hypothalamus within physiological limits distinguish sleep from wakefulness </s>
<s> thus a low intensity of hypothalamic-cortical discharges prevails in sleep and a high one during wakefulness resulting in synchronous eeg potentials in the former and asynchrony in the latter condition </s>
<s> with the dominance of the sympathetic division of the hypothalamus the opposite changes occur </s>
<s> since electrical stimulation of the posterior hypothalamus produces the effects of wakefulness while stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus induces sleep it may be said that the reactivity of the whole organism is altered by a change in the autonomic reactivity of the hypothalamus </s>
<s> similar effects can be induced reflexly via the baroreceptor reflexes in man and animals </s>
<s> of particular importance is the study of the actions of drugs in this respect </s>
<s> although no drugs act exclusively on the hypothalamus or a part of it there is sufficient specificity to distinguish drugs which shift the hypothalamic balance to the sympathetic side from those which produce a parasympathetic dominance </s>
<s> the former comprise analeptic and psychoactive drugs the latter the tranquilizers </s>
<s> specific differences exist in the action of different drugs belonging to the same group as for instance between reserpine and chlorpromazine </s>
<s> important as these differences are they should not obscure the basic fact that by shifting the hypothalamic balance sufficiently to the parasympathetic side we produce depressions whereas a shift in the opposite direction causes excitatory effects and eventually maniclike changes </s>
<s> the emotional states produced by drugs influence the cortical potentials in a characteristic manner </s>
<s> synchrony prevails in the eeg of the experimental animal after administration of tranquilizers but asynchrony after application of analeptic and psychoactive drugs </s>
<s> the shock therapies act likewise on the hypothalamic balance </s>
<s> physiological experiments and clinical observations have shown that these procedures influence the hypothalamically controlled hypophyseal secretions and increase sympathetic discharges </s>
<s> they shift the hypothalamic balance to the sympathetic side </s>
<s> this explains the beneficial effect of electroshock therapy in certain depressions and a shift in the reaction from hypo- to normal reactivity of the sympathetic system as shown by the mecholyl test </s>
<s> some investigators have found a parallelism between remissions and return of the sympathetic reactivity of the hypothalamus to the normal level as indicated by the mecholyl test and conversely between clinical impairment and increasing deviation of this test from the norm </s>
<s> nevertheless the theory that the determining influence of the hypothalamic balance has a profound influence on the clinical behavior of neuropsychiatric patients has not yet been tested on an adequate number of patients </s>
<s> the mecholyl and noradrenalin tests applied with certain precautions are reliable indicators of this central autonomic balance but for the sake of correlating autonomic and clinical states and of studying the effect of certain therapeutic procedures on central autonomic reactions additional tests seem to be desirable </s>
<s> it was assumed that the shift in autonomic hypothalamic balance occurring spontaneously in neuropsychiatric patients from the application of certain therapeutic procedures follows the pattern known from the sleep-wakefulness cycle </s>
<s> a change in the balance to the parasympathetic side leads in the normal individual to sleep or in special circumstances to cardiovascular collapse or nausea and vomiting </s>
<s> in both conditions the emotional and perceptual sensitivity is diminished but no depression occurs such as is seen clinically or may be produced in normal persons by drugs </s>
<s> perhaps a clue to these and related problems lies in the fact that changes in the intensity of hypothalamic discharges which are associated with changes in its balance lead also to qualitative alterations in reactivity </s>
<s> if for instance such a change is produced by one or a few insulin comas or electroshocks previously inhibited conditioned reactions reappear </s>
<s> however if these procedures are applied more often conditioned emotional responses are temporarily abolished </s>
<s> these are few and seemingly disjointed data but they illustrate the important fact that fundamental alterations in conditioned reactions occur in a variety of states in which the hypothalamic balance has been altered by physiological experimentation pharmacological action or clinical processes </s>
<s> on the physiological basis of some form of psychotherapy </s>
<s> the foregoing remarks imply that the hypothalamic balance plays a crucial role at the crossroads between physiological and pathological forms of emotion </s>
<s> if this is the case one would expect that not only the various procedures just mentioned which alter the hypothalamic balance would influence emotional state and behavior but that emotion itself would act likewise </s>
<s> this phenomenon raises the question whether the guidance of the emotions for therapeutic ends may not have an even wider application in the area of the neuroses </s>
<s> being a strictly physiological procedure one may expect from such a study additional information on the nature of the emotional process itself </s>
<s> an important observation of pavlov served as a guide post to achieve such a reversibility by physiological means </s>
<s> in a conditioning experiment he demonstrated the antagonism between feeding and pain </s>
<s> a mild electrical shock served as a conditioned stimulus and was followed by feeding </s>
<s> even when the intensity of the shocks was increased gradually it failed to evoke any signs of pain </s>
<s> since strong nociceptive stimuli produce an experimental neurosis during which the animals fail to eat in the experimental situation wolpe thought that he could utilize the feeding-pain antagonism to inhibit the neurotic symptoms through feeding </s>
<s> appropriate experiments showed that this is indeed possible </s>
<s> he then applied this principle of reciprocal inhibition to human neuroses </s>
<s> he took advantage of the antagonism between aggressive assertiveness and anxiety and found a relatively rapid disappearance of anxiety when the former attitude was established </s>
<s> for the interpretation of these significant investigations it should be remembered that reciprocal relations exist in the hypothalamus with respect to autonomic and somatic functions which are closely associated with the emotions </s>
<s> the feeding-pain antagonism seems to be based on this reciprocal relation between the tropho- and ergotropic systems </s>
<s> furthermore a functional antagonism exists between an aggressive attitude and a state of anxiety </s>
<s> although in both emotions sympathetic symptoms are present different autonomic-somatic patterns underlie aggression and anxiety respectively as indicated by the rate of the excretion of the catecholamines the state of the muscle tone and the mecholyl test </s>
<s> the psychological incompatibility of these emotional states seems to be reflected in or based on this marked difference </s>
<s> concluding remarks </s>
<s> in our attempt to interpret the emotions in their physiological and pathological range we emphasized the importance of the degree of activity of the parasympathetic and sympathetic divisions of the hypothalamic system and their influence on the inhibitory and excitatory systems respectively </s>
<s> we stressed the reciprocal relation of these systems with respect to the autonomic-somatic downward discharge as well as regarding the hypothalamic-cortical discharge </s>
<s> although we are still far from a complete understanding of these problems as a first approximation it is suggested that alterations in the hypothalamic balance with consequent changes in the hypothalamic-cortical discharges account for major changes in behavior seen in various moods and states of emotions in man and beast under physiological circumstances in experimental and clinical neurosis and as the result of psychopharmacological agents </s>
<s> in view of the important role which emotional disturbances play in the genesis of neurotic and psychotic disorders and the parallelism observed between autonomic states and psychological behavior in several instances it is further suggested that a hypothalamic imbalance may play an important role in initiating mental changes </s>
<s> the primary decomposition theorem </s>
<s> we are trying to study a linear operator t on the finite-dimensional space v by decomposing t into a direct sum of operators which are in some sense elementary </s>

<s> this is really a deficiency in the scalar field namely that it is not algebraically closed </s>
<s> this is clearly a deficiency in t </s>
<s> thus t is not diagonalizable </s>
<s> on the other hand the null space of af and the null space of af together span v the former being the subspace spanned by af and the latter the subspace spanned by af and af </s>
<s> this will be more or less our general method for the second problem </s>

<s> corollary </s>
<s> let v be a finite-dimensional vector space over an algebraically closed field f eg the field of complex numbers </s>
<s> then every linear operator t in v can be written as the sum of a diagonalizable operator d and a nilpotent operator n which commute </s>
<s> these operators d and n are unique and each is a polynomial in t </s>
<s> from these results one sees that the study of linear operators on vector spaces over an algebraically closed field is essentially reduced to the study of nilpotent operators </s>
<s> for vector spaces over non-algebraically closed fields we still need to find some substitute for characteristic values and vectors </s>
<s> it is a very interesting fact that these two problems can be handled simultaneously and this is what we shall do in the next chapter </s>
<s> in concluding this section we should like to give an example which illustrates some of the ideas of the primary decomposition theorem </s>

<s> we now write af where af are distinct complex numbers </s>
<s> in other words if f satisfies the differential equation af then f is uniquely expressible in the form af where af satisfies the differential equation af </s>
<s> thus the study of the solutions to the equation af is reduced to the study of the space of solutions of a differential equation of the form af </s>
<s> this reduction has been accomplished by the general methods of linear algebra ie by the primary decomposition theorem </s>
<s> to describe the space of solutions to af one must know something about differential equations </s>
<s> that is one must know something about d other than the fact that it is a linear operator </s>
<s> however one does not need to know very much </s>

<s> accordingly the functions af span the space of solutions of af </s>

<s> examples of binomial experiments </s>
<s> some experiments are composed of repetitions of independent trials each with two possible outcomes </s>
<s> the binomial probability distribution may describe the variation that occurs from one set of trials of such a binomial experiment to another </s>
<s> we devote a chapter to the binomial distribution not only because it is a mathematical model for an enormous variety of real life phenomena but also because it has important properties that recur in many other probability models </s>
<s> we begin with a few examples of binomial experiments </s>
<s> marksmanship example </s>
<s> inheritance in mice </s>
<s> general binomial problem </s>
<s> fortunately a general formula of wide applicability solves all problems of this kind </s>
<s> experiments are often composed of several identical trials and sometimes experiments themselves are repeated </s>
<s> further an experiment might consist of five rounds and several sets of five rounds might be regarded as a super-experiment composed of several repetitions of the five-round experiment </s>
<s> if three dice are tossed a trial is one toss of one die and the experiment is composed of three trials </s>
<s> or what amounts to the same thing if one die is tossed three times each toss is a trial and the three tosses form the experiment </s>
<s> mathematically we shall not distinguish the experiment of three dice tossed once from that of one die tossed three times </s>
<s> student football managers </s>
<s> ten students act as managers for a high-school football team and of these managers a proportion p are licensed drivers </s>
<s> each friday one manager is chosen by lot to stay late and load the equipment on a truck </s>
<s> on three fridays the coach has needed a driver </s>
<s> discussion </s>
<s> each trial consists of choosing a student manager at random </s>
<s> since the choice is by lot each week the outcomes of different trials are independent </s>
<s> the managers stay the same so that af is the same for all weeks </s>
<s> we now generalize these ideas for general binomial experiments </s>
<s> below we use our earlier examples to describe and illustrate these four properties </s>
<s> we also give for each property an example where the property is absent </s>
<s> the language and notation introduced are standard throughout the chapter </s>
<s> there must be a fixed number n of repeated trials </s>
<s> experiment without a fixed number of trials </s>
<s> toss a die until an ace appears </s>
<s> here the number of trials is a random variable not a fixed number </s>
<s> binomial trials </s>
<s> each of the n trials is either a success or a failure </s>
<s> experiment without the two-class property </s>
<s> we can escape from such a difficulty by ruling out the animal as not constituting a trial but such a solution is not always satisfactory </s>
<s> all trials have identical probabilities of success </s>
<s> each die has probability af of producing an ace </s>
<s> note that we need not know the value of p for the experiment to be binomial </s>
<s> experiment where p is not constant </s>
<s> the trials are independent </s>
<s> strictly speaking this means that the probability for each possible outcome of the experiment can be computed by multiplying together the probabilities of the possible outcomes of the single binomial trials </s>
<s> thus in the three-dice example af af and the independence assumption imply that the probability that the three dice fall ace not-ace ace in that order is af </s>
<s> experimentally we expect independence when the trials have nothing to do with one another </s>
<s> examples where independence fails </s>
<s> a family of five plans to go together either to the beach or to the mountains and a coin is tossed to decide </s>
<s> we want to know the number of people going to the mountains </s>
<s> when this experiment is viewed as composed of five binomial trials one for each member of the family the outcomes of the trials are obviously not independent </s>
<s> indeed the experiment is better viewed as consisting of one binomial trial for the entire family </s>
<s> the following is a less extreme example of dependence </s>
<s> consider couples visiting an art museum </s>
<s> each person votes for one of a pair of pictures to receive a popular prize </s>
<s> an experiment consists of the voting of one couple or two trials </s>
<s> in repetitions of the experiment from couple to couple the votes of the two persons in a couple probably agree more often than independence would imply because couples who visit the museum together are more likely to have similar tastes than are a random pair of people drawn from the entire population of visitors </s>
<s> we want to study the probability function of this random variable </s>
<s> a binomial experiment can produce random variables other than the number of successes </s>
<s> the constancy of p and the independence are the conditions most likely to give trouble in practice </s>
<s> obviously very slight changes in p do not change the probabilities much and a slight lack of independence may not make an appreciable difference </s>
<s> that is we may discuss the phenomenon in terms of its departures from the binomial model </s>
<s> to summarize </s>
<s> a binomial experiment consists of af independent binomial trials all with the same probability af of yielding a success </s>
<s> the outcome of the experiment is x successes </s>
<s> the random variable x takes the values af with probabilities af or more briefly af </s>
<s> we shall find a formula for the probability of exactly x successes for given values of p and n </s>
<s> when each number of successes x is paired with its probability of occurrence af the set of pairs af is a probability function called a binomial distribution </s>
<s> random variables </s>
<s> the several trials of a binomial experiment produce a new random variable x the total number of successes which is just the sum of the random variables associated with the single trials </s>
<s> their sum is x the total number of successes which in this experiment has the value af </s>
<s> consider a simple closed plane curve c which is a real-analytic image of the unit circle and which is given by af </s>
<s> these are real analytic periodic functions with period t </s>
<s> in the following paper it is shown that in a certain definite sense exactly an odd number of squares can be inscribed in every such curve which does not contain an infinite number of inscribed squares </s>
<s> this theorem is similar to the theorem of kakutani that there exists a circumscribing cube around any closed bounded convex set in af </s>
<s> the latter theorem has been generalized by yamabe and yujobo and cairns to show that in af there are families of such cubes </s>
<s> here for the case of squares inscribed in plane curves we remove the restriction to convexity and give certain other results </s>
<s> a square inscribed in a curve c means a square with its four corner points on the curve though it may not lie entirely in the interior of c </s>
<s> indeed the spiral af with the two endpoints connected by a straight line possesses only one inscribed square </s>
<s> the square has one corner point on the straight line segment and does not lie entirely in the interior </s>
<s> on c from the point p at af to the point q at af we construct the chord and upon the chord as a side erect a square in such a way that as s approaches zero the square is inside c </s>
<s> as s increases we consider the two free corner points of the square af and af adjacent to p and q respectively </s>
<s> as s approaches t the square will be outside c and therefore both af and af must cross c an odd number of times as s varies from zero to t </s>
<s> the points may also touch c without crossing </s>
<s> suppose af crosses c when af </s>
<s> we now have certain squares with three corners on c </s>
<s> for any such square the middle corner of these will be called the vertex of the square and the corner not on the curve will be called the diagonal point of the square </s>
<s> each point on c as a vertex may possess a finite number of corresponding diagonal points by the above construction </s>
<s> to each paired vertex and diagonal point there corresponds a unique forward corner point ie the corner on c reached first by proceeding along c from the vertex in the direction of increasing t </s>
<s> the set of intersections of af the rotated curve with the original curve c consists of just the set of forward corner points on c corresponding to the vertex at af plus the vertex itself </s>
<s> we note that two such curves c and af cannot coincide at more than a finite number of points </s>
<s> otherwise being analytic they would coincide at all points which is impossible since they do not coincide near af </s>
<s> with each vertex we associate certain numerical values namely the set of positive differences in the parameter t between the vertex and its corresponding forward corner points </s>
<s> for the vertex at af these values will be denoted by af </s>
<s> we will refer to the plane of c and af as the c-plane and to the plane of the graph as the aj </s>
<s> the graph as a set may have a finite number of components </s>
<s> each point with abscissa t on the graph represents an intersection between c and af </s>
<s> there are two types of such intersections depending essentially on whether the curves cross at the point of intersection </s>
<s> an ordinary point will be any point of intersection a such that in every neighborhood of a in the c-plane af meets both the interior and the exterior of c </s>
<s> any other point of intersection between c and af will be called a tangent point </s>
<s> this terminology will also be applied to the corresponding points in the aj </s>
<s> we can now prove several lemmas </s>
<s> in some neighborhood in the f-plane of any ordinary point of the graph the function f is a single-valued continuous function </s>
<s> proof </s>
<s> we first show that the function is single-valued in some neighborhood </s>
<s> with the vertex at af in the c-plane we assume that af is the parametric location on c of an ordinary intersection q between c and af </s>
<s> in the f-plane the coordinates of the corresponding point are af </s>
<s> we know that in the c-plane both c and af are analytic </s>
<s> in the c-plane we construct a set of rectangular cartesian coordinates u v with the origin at q and such that both c and af have finite slope at q </s>
<s> near q both curves can be represented by analytic functions of u </s>
<s> in a neighborhood of q the difference between these functions is also a single-valued analytic function of u </s>
<s> furthermore one can find a neighborhood of q in which the difference function is monotone for since it is analytic it can have only a finite number of extrema in any interval </s>
<s> now to find af one needs the intersection of c and af near q </s>
<s> the arc is itself a segment of an analytic curve </s>
<s> thus if e is sufficiently small there can be only one intersection of c and af near q for if there were more than one intersection for every e then the difference between c and af near q would not be a monotone function </s>
<s> therefore af is single-valued near q </s>
<s> it is also seen that af since the change from af to af is accomplished by a continuous translation </s>
<s> thus af is also continuous at af and in a neighborhood of af which does not contain a tangent point </s>
<s> we turn now to the set of tangent points on the graph </s>
<s> this set must consist of isolated points and closed intervals </s>
<s> this prevents the occurrence of an infinite sequence of isolated tangent points </s>
<s> in some neighborhood of an isolated tangent point in the f-plane say af the function af is either double-valued or has no values defined except at the tangent point itself where it is single-valued </s>
<s> proof </s>
<s> a tangent point q in the c-plane occurs when c and af are tangent to one another </s>
<s> a continuous change in t through an amount e results in a translation along an analytic arc of the curve af </s>
<s> in the second category the function af has no values defined in a neighborhood af </s>
<s> in the third category the function is double-valued in this interval </s>
<s> the same remarks apply to an interval on the other side of af </s>
<s> again the analyticity of the two curves guarantees that such intervals exist </s>
<s> in the neighborhood of an end point of an interval of tangent points in the f-plane the function is two-valued or no-valued on one side and is a single-valued function consisting entirely of tangent points on the other side </s>
<s> with the above results we can make the following remarks about the graph of f </s>
<s> definition </s>
<s> the graph of f has at least one component whose support is the entire interval aj </s>
<s> proof </s>
<s> we suppose not </s>
<s> then every component of the graph of f must be defined over a bounded sub-interval </s>
<s> suppose af is defined in the sub-interval af </s>
<s> now af and af must both be tangent points on the t component in the f-plane </s>
<s> thus the multiplicity of af for a given t must be an even number </s>
<s> this is true of all components which have such a bounded support </s>
<s> there must be an odd number of such components which will be called complete components </s>
<s> we must now show that on some component of the graph there exist two points for which the corresponding diagonal points in the c-plane are on opposite sides of c </s>
<s> we again consider a fixed point p at af and a variable point q at af on c </s>
<s> we erect a square with pq as a side and with free corners af and af adjacent to p and q respectively </s>
<s> as s varies from zero to t the values of s for which af and af cross c will be denoted by af and af respectively </s>
<s> we have af plus tangent points </s>
<s> these s-values are just the ordinary values of af </s>
<s> proof </s>
<s> the functions f and b have exactly the same multiplicity at every argument t </s>
<s> now with p fixed at af af-values occur when the corner af crosses c and are among the values of s such that af </s>
<s> introduction </s>
<s> these are defined by a simple involutorial transformation of the points in which a general line meets a nonsingular quadric surface bearing a curve of symbol af </s>
<s> no generalization of these results to spaces of more than three dimensions has so far been found possible </s>
<s> a general line l meets q in two points af and af through each of which passes a unique generator of the regulus af whose lines are simple secants of aj </s>
<s> on these generators let af and af be respectively the harmonic conjugates of af and af with respect to the two points in which the corresponding generator meets aj </s>
<s> the line af is the image of l </s>
<s> clearly the transformation is involutorial </s>
<s> we observe first that no line l can meet its image except at one of its intersections with q </s>
<s> for if it did the plane of l and l would contain two generators of af which is impossible </s>
<s> moreover from the definitive transformation of intercepts on the generators of af it is clear that the only points of q at which a line can meet its image are the points of aj </s>
<s> hence the totality of singular lines is the t order complex of lines which meet aj </s>
<s> since the complex of singular lines is of order k and since there is no complex of invariant lines it follows from the formula af that the order of the involution is af </s>
<s> there are various sets of exceptional lines or lines whose images are not unique </s>
<s> the most obvious of these is the quadratic complex of tangents to q each line of which is transformed into the entire pencil of lines tangent to q at the image of the point of tangency of the given line </s>
<s> thus pencils of tangents to q are transformed into pencils of tangents </s>
<s> in particular tangents to c are transformed into tangents to c </s>
<s> moreover if af and af are two planes intersecting in a line l tangent to q at a point p the two free intersections of the image curves af and af must coincide at p the image of p and at this point af and af must have a common tangent l </s>
<s> the congruence of its secants is therefore of order af and class af </s>
<s> a final class of exceptional lines is identifiable from the following considerations since no two generators of af can intersect it follows that their image curves can have no free intersections </s>
<s> in other words these curves have only fixed intersections common to them all </s>
<s> since two curves of symbol af on q intersect in af points it follows that there are af lines of af which are tangent to aj </s>
<s> hence its image c meets any line of af in af points </s>
<s> moreover c obviously meets any line af in a single point </s>
<s> hence c is a af curve on q </s>
<s> therefore the congruence of its secants that is the image of a general plane field of lines is of order af and class af </s>
<s> finally the image of a general bundle of lines is a congruence whose order is the order of the congruence of invariant lines namely af and whose class is the order of the image congruence of a general plane field of lines namely af </s>
<s> we now shall show that any involution with these characteristics is necessarily of the type we have just described </s>
<s> to see this consider a general pencil of lines containing a general secant of aj </s>
<s> on c there is a af correspondence in which the af points cut from c by a general line l of the pencil correspond to the point of intersection of the image of l and the plane of the pencil </s>
<s> since c is rational this correspondence has k coincidences each of which implies a line of the pencil which meets its image </s>
<s> from the preceding remarks it is clear that such a bundle is transformed into itself in an involutorial fashion </s>
<s> hence it follows that the involution within the bundle must be a perspective de jonquieres involution of order af and the invariant locus must have a multiple line of multiplicity either af or af </s>
<s> in each case lines of the bundles are transformed by involutions within the pencils they determine with the multiple secant </s>
<s> the multiple secants of course are exceptional and in each case are transformed into cones of order af </s>
<s> observations similar to these can be made at each point of aj </s>
<s> moreover if af no two of the multiple secants can intersect </s>
<s> however if there is no additional complex of singular lines the order of the image regulus of a pencil is precisely af </s>
